title: The Silk Road: Connecting the ancient world through trade - Shannon Harris Castelo

multiple-choice.question: What was the Silk Road in history?

options.label: A
options.text: A single road connecting Europe and Asia

options.label: B
options.text: A network of multiple routes connecting various settlements

options.label: C
options.text: A maritime trade route across the ocean

multiple-choice.question: Which nomadic tribe played a significant role in spreading goods and ideas between cultures along the Silk Road?
What was the Persian Royal Road, and when was it completed?

options.label: A
options.text: A 2,000-mile road from the Tigris River to the Aegean Sea, completed by Alexander the Great

options.label: B
options.text: A 2,000-mile road from the Tigris River to the Aegean Sea, completed by Darius the First in the 5th century BCE

options.label: C
options.text: A maritime trade route across the ocean, completed by the Romans

options.label: D
options.text: A network of routes connecting Europe and Asia, completed by the Mongolians

multiple-choice.question: Who was the ambassador that returned to the Han Emperor with tales of sophisticated civilizations, prosperous trade, and exotic goods beyond the western borders?
What was one of the significant outcomes of the cultural and commercial exchange between East and West along the Silk Road?

options.label: A
options.text: The spread of Buddhism from India to China and Japan

options.label: B
options.text: The transmission of crossbow technology from China to the Western world

options.label: C
options.text: The ban on silk in Rome due to the outflow of gold

multiple-choice.question: Which empire actively protected the trade routes of the Silk Road, despite being known for pillage and plunder?
What was one of the factors that led to the decline of the Silk Road?

options.label: B
options.text: The withdrawal of China from international trade

options.label: C
options.text: The development of new maritime technologies in Europe

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Europeans seeking new maritime routes to the riches of East Asia?

options.label: A
options.text: The Age of Exploration and expansion into Africa and the Americas

options.label: B
options.text: The decline of the Silk Road

options.label: C
options.text: The rise of the Mongolian Empire

options.label: D
options.text: The spread of Buddhism from India to China and Japan

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of globalization on culture and economy, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a new phenomenon with only benefits

options.label: B
options.text: It is a new phenomenon with only drawbacks

options.label: C
options.text: It is not a new phenomenon and has both benefits and drawbacks

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a new phenomenon and has no impact

multiple-choice.question: What is the Silk Road referred to as in the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: The ancient network of trade routes

title: How does your brain respond to pain? - Karen D. Davis

multiple-choice.question: What is pain defined as in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A physical sensation associated with injury

options.label: B
options.text: An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage

What is the salience network responsible for in the context of pain?

options.label: C
options.text: Deciding what to pay attention to

multiple-choice.question: What chemicals are released by the brain in response to pain or extreme exercise?

options.label: B
options.text: Due to differences in brain structure

options.label: C
options.text: Due to differences in coping mechanisms

options.label: D
options.text: Due to differences in emotional response

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of pain treatments?
What type of therapy can be used to help people cope with pain?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for more effective treatment of chronic pain

options.label: B
options.text: It reduces the risk of side effects

options.label: C
options.text: It tailors treatment to individual patients

multiple-choice.question: What tool can be used to map brain pathways and tailor pain treatment to individual patients?
What is the term for pain that persists months after an injury should have healed?

title: How languages evolve - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: According to the biblical story of the Tower of Babel, what event led to the creation of multiple languages?

options.label: B
options.text: A sudden split of humanity into many groups

options.label: D
options.text: The creation of a new alphabet

What type of words are less likely to be borrowed and can help linguists determine language relationships?

options.label: B
options.text: Basic vocabulary (e.g. pronouns, numbers, kinship terms)

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main problems linguists face when constructing language family trees?

options.label: A
options.text: Deciding where the branches at the bottom should end

options.label: B
options.text: Determining the geographic origins of ancient peoples

options.label: C
options.text: Reconstructing earlier languages with no written records

multiple-choice.question: Why can the difference between languages and dialects be unclear?

options.label: B
options.text: Due to changing political and national considerations

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated range of the number of languages in the world, depending on who's counting?
What is the current limit at which relationships between languages can be established with reasonable certainty?
What is the term used to describe proposed higher-level relationships between languages?
According to the transcript, what may never be determined about language?

options.label: B
options.text: Whether all human languages had a common ancestor

options.label: C
options.text: The number of languages in the world

title: How the heart actually pumps blood - Edmond Hui

multiple-choice.question: What was the historical understanding of the heart's purpose in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: It was well understood as a blood-pumping organ.

options.label: B
options.text: It was believed to be a non-essential organ.

options.label: C
options.text: Its purpose was not clearly understood.

options.label: D
options.text: It was thought to be responsible for breathing.

multiple-choice.question: Why was it difficult for people to understand the heart's function?

options.label: A
options.text: The heart is a simple organ with few parts.

options.label: B
options.text: The blood vessels are transparent, making it easy to observe.

options.label: C
options.text: The body would perish quickly if the heart was exposed or taken out.

options.label: D
options.text: The heart is a well-studied organ in surgery teams.

multiple-choice.question: What is the correct description of the circulation of blood in mammals?

options.label: A
options.text: Dual-circulation with one loop to the lungs and another to the body.

options.label: B
options.text: Figure-eight circulation with two heart pumps and two loops.

options.label: C
options.text: Single-circulation with one loop to the lungs and body.

options.label: D
options.text: Triple-circulation with three loops to the lungs, body, and brain.

multiple-choice.question: Why do students often struggle to understand the heart's function in biology lessons?

options.label: A
options.text: The heart is an intimidating subject with complicated names and diagrams.

options.label: B
options.text: The heart is a simple organ with few parts.

options.label: C
options.text: The heart is not an essential organ in the human body.

options.label: D
options.text: The heart is only studied in medicine.

multiple-choice.question: What is required to demonstrate the heart's pumping mechanism?

options.label: A
options.text: A whole fresh heart immersed in water.

options.label: B
options.text: A diagram or animation of the heart.

options.label: C
options.text: A model of the heart with labeled parts.

options.label: D
options.text: A surgery team to observe the heart in action.

multiple-choice.question: Why doesn't the heart pump when squeezed by hand while immersed in water?

options.label: A
options.text: The water enters the heart cleanly enough for the pumping mechanism to work.

options.label: B
options.text: The water doesn't enter the heart cleanly enough for the pumping mechanism to work.

options.label: C
options.text: The heart is not a pumping organ.

options.label: D
options.text: The water is too cold for the heart to function.

options.label: A
options.text: To make the heart look more complicated.

options.label: B
options.text: To remove the incoming veins attached to the atria.

options.label: C
options.text: To make the heart look less complicated.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when water is run into the right ventricle from a tap?

options.label: B
options.text: The ventricular valve tries to close against the incoming stream.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the ventricular valves in the heart?

options.label: A
options.text: To pump blood out of the heart.

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate the flow of blood into the heart.

options.label: C
options.text: To close against the incoming stream of blood and prevent backflow.

multiple-choice.question: How many beats does a heart give in its lifetime?

options.text: To store the antibodies for later use
